item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: iKy
item.description:
it is expected that the majority of people who will be talking about this are cocky idiots who think if you instantly oppose something new you are rated as an intelectual / critic , but with no material argument , the only issue i see with onlive is distribution , remember those who talk about 2mb/s and stuff that it uses an close-to-perfect archivation process who is revolutionary , that IS the big thing about onlive ,everything else is old , we all know it has been tried before n shizz , but then they didn’t upgrade the netcode , now a netcode seems to work , also , you should bring arguments to why it will fail [ like some idiots don’t ]

Read full topic

item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: FlotsamX
item.description:
megiddo:

Its a great idea for internet cafes, would cut the cost of upgrading gaming rigs because customers have access to run all games all you have to do is buy the onlive client like a steam account.

That cafe would need a helluva connection to support 30 people streaming 2MB persecond HD video.

item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: eternalness
item.description:
Heres my list of how onlive will fail:

  1. Onlive by some miracle becomes popular.
  2. Their games look really good at first because of that special technology thing they had for face design and other stuff, and it would run the games at decent fps.
  3. People stop buying new comps and upgrades for their comps.
  4. Computer and computer component companies lose money and start to go out of buisness since their only big buyer is onlive, which I doubt would buy enough stuff to support all these companies.
  5. Advances in comercially availible computer technology slows down.
  6. Eventually the game will stop advancing in technology due to the fact that the technology powering them isn’t advancing.
  7. Onlive FAILS.
  8. World ends.

Read full topic

item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: indeed
item.description:
There is just something scary, about not owning any of your games and being stuck playing single player games over the internet. There are enough people out there, still bitching about Steam and how you need an Internet connection, to play an offline game. Then, there’s the fee you will have to pay, together with your ISP’s special “3 month’s of free gaming” and 149.99 $ a month special.
It is destined to fail!

Read full topic

iKy:

i think everyone who knows about this applied for the beta , including meh

Ick, you signed up for this piece of shit?

Enjoy paying a fee every month to play games you never actually own.

This thing will never catch on, it would completely rape the mod industry.

item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: Ford_Prefect
item.description:
Well, I signed up for the beta so I could try it for free. If I get in I’ll let you guys know if it performs as well as they say it does (unless of course there’s an NDA, in which case I’ll tell you after the NDA is lifted.)

Not sure if there will be an NDA cause what could I possibly tell you about it that you couldn’t find out from the website? There may be some games on the service that would want an NDA, but for the service itself I really don’t see a need. Doesn’t mean they won’t do it tho.

Read full topic

item.title: Onlive: Revolution or Total mistake?
item.dc:creator: Level
item.description:
I think this is still a few years too early. IMO, there needs to be faster worldwide internet connections first, because that’s what this technology relies on.
I know I won’t use this service as soon as it comes out, but maybe 5 or so years down the line I might try it out.
